page.syntax: Current_State as L = ControlEnable as L(index as N,flag as L)

argument.name: index
argument.description: Index specifies which button on the toolbar that is set. An Index value of 1 specifies the first button on the toolbar.

argument.name: flag
argument.description: .T. = Enable the button, .F. = Disable the button

page.discussion: The .CONTROLENABLE() method sets that status of a button on a toolbar to either enabled or disabled. The toolbar is specified by the object pointer, . If you want to control the state of buttons on system toolbars (i.e. toolbars that are opened automatically by a Form, Browse, Print Preview window), then you must first get a pointer to the system toolbar before you can use this method. Use the TOOLBAR.GET() method to get a pointer to a toolbar whose name you know. TIP : A toolbar's name can be determined by undocking the toolbar so that it is floating, and checking the title that appears in the toolbar title bar. Limitations: Desktop applications only.
page.example: dim tbar as P tbar = toolbar.open("My Own Toolbar") tbar.controlenable(3, .T.) 'The following disables the 3 rd control on the default toolbar in 'Form View '----------------------------------------------------------------- tbar = toolbar.get("Form View") tbar.controlenable(3,.f.)
